body: I am seeing this error when compiling `rust-curl` for cargo.

I reproduced it on that version exactly, on Debian GNU/Linux. Verbose output:

```
     Running `rustc /home/keegan/.cargo/git/checkouts/string-cache-628f0438d3df3ef7/master/src/lib.rs --crate-name string_cache --crate-type lib -g -C metadata=1cf14970ab03ef33 -C extra-filename=-1cf14970ab03ef33 --out-dir /home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps --dep-info /home/keegan/html5ever/target/.fingerprint/string_cache-1cf14970ab03ef33/dep-lib-string_cache -L /home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps -L /home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps --extern string_cache_macros=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libstring_cache_macros-c486c481d0b8fc2d.so --extern xxhash=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libxxhash-0275196ad61a41f5.rlib --extern phf_mac=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libphf_mac-78b8694be35c3487.so --extern phf=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libphf-4fc01267f85abb4e.rlib --extern lazy_static=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/liblazy_static-518089d616e0fe56.rlib`
rustc: /home/keegan/rust-master/src/llvm/include/llvm/Support/CommandLine.h:682: void llvm::cl::parser<DataType>::addLiteralOption(const char*, const DT&, const char*) [with DT = llvm::ScheduleDAGSDNodes* (*)(llvm::SelectionDAGISel*, llvm::CodeGenOpt::Level); DataType = llvm::ScheduleDAGSDNodes* (*)(llvm::SelectionDAGISel*, llvm::CodeGenOpt::Level)]: Assertion `findOption(Name) == Values.size() && "Option already exists!"' failed.
Could not compile `string_cache`.

Caused by:
  Process didn't exit successfully: `rustc /home/keegan/.cargo/git/checkouts/string-cache-628f0438d3df3ef7/master/src/lib.rs --crate-name string_cache --crate-type lib -g -C metadata=1cf14970ab03ef33 -C extra-filename=-1cf14970ab03ef33 --out-dir /home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps --dep-info /home/keegan/html5ever/target/.fingerprint/string_cache-1cf14970ab03ef33/dep-lib-string_cache -L /home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps -L /home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps --extern string_cache_macros=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libstring_cache_macros-c486c481d0b8fc2d.so --extern xxhash=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libxxhash-0275196ad61a41f5.rlib --extern phf_mac=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libphf_mac-78b8694be35c3487.so --extern phf=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/libphf-4fc01267f85abb4e.rlib --extern lazy_static=/home/keegan/html5ever/target/deps/liblazy_static-518089d616e0fe56.rlib -Awarnings` (status=6)
```

```
#35 0x00007ffff634ec2d in clone () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/clone.S:111
```

So there's a static constructor in part of LLVM that got linked into the `phf_mac` compiler plugin, and `libdl` runs this when the plugin is loaded, but rustc has (presumably) already run those static constructors, which causes LLVM to complain about a duplicated option.  Lovely.
@kmc that looks like something statically linked to LLVM and we're dlopen()ing another copy which is causing a panic in LLVM itself, not quite sure where that's coming from though...
I got this error with libhoare (syntax extension) when building as a static lib. Changing to build as dynamic lib fixed it (`-C prefer-dynamic` when building the syntax extension).

I'm still seeing this, now on rustc 0.13.0-dev (c8d6e3b2c 2014-11-18 19:11:43 +0000).

We have

``` toml
[lib]
name = "string_cache_macros"
plugin = true
```

under `macros/Cargo.toml` and

``` rust
#![crate_type="dylib"]
```

in `macros/src/lib.rs`.  Looking in `target/deps/` I see that both `string_cache_macros` and `phf_mac` are built as dylibs.
@alexcrichton, @nick29581: What information from me would be helpful in reproducing this problem?

I fixed this by upgrading to a version of Cargo that passes `-C prefer-dynamic`; thanks @alexcrichton!

I'm keeping this bug open because we should handle it more gracefully than an LLVM assertion (which is UB in a no-asserts build).

Traige: since cargo does this correctly now, I'm guessing that's why nobody has hit this, but I am not aware of any improvements, and agree with @kmcallister that it'd be better to handle this more gracefully.
Triage; with no comments here since 2014, I'm going to give this a close. If you're still running into this today, please let me know!
